title: Points, a discussion.
content:
I've just been looking over the old levelpacks and my old [pre ShadowKeen 1] mods, and was shocked by some of the atrocious level design in some of them. Specifically I noticed some horrible point item distribution [Some levelpacks worse than my first mods.] As such I have developed 7 point rules I now use in my levels and ro design points. I'd like to hear what you think makes a good point item.

Teh Rulez:

1.) Keen shouldn't be able to get points just by walking around. He should at least have to jump or navigate to where they are.

2.) Use points to indicate jumps, etc Use low value items for this and do it creatively.

3.) Think of each set of items as being in an area, ask yourself 'how hard is it to get into this area?' and value the points accordingly.

4.) Its best to have several low value items, especially if you want to spread them around to liven up your level, but its good to keep at least one item that is high value and used only sparingly.

5.) Items cannot decorate the level. They are an added extra to by laid over the level after its done. Don't fill blank space with points as it looks repetitive and when the points are got, the space will still be there.

6.) Make your points look gettable, and attractive.

7.) Theme your items to your mod.

title: right on
content:
Excellent points, LL. This goes a bit further into level design, but some mods have points tucked away behind doors by keys which are optional and not necessary to complete a level. Please, modders, either make the optional stuff a specific color, or at least mention in your readme.txt that there's a lot of optional stuff.

Another useful thing to do, back in the DOS-based KeenWright days, was to make liberal use of that Level Statistics option. Don't be afraid to put more than 1 extra life's worth in points in a level--as long as the level is of appropriate size, and the points are risky enough to allow it. I bet with a little work, someone could come up with a formula to calculate how many points there are per un-blocking tile. :-) That'd be nifty.

Also, LL, I think you should consider opening a discussion like this at K:M to go over alternate ways to spruce up the background of your mod. Your mods almost always have very elaborate side stuff--I'm curious to know your technique.

title: Indeed.
content:
[hr]LevelLord 1.) Keen shouldn't be able to get points just by walking around. He should at least have to jump or navigate to where they are.
[hr]This is one of the cardinal level-design rules I've come to adopt. What's the... *avoids pun* purpose... in having point items if they're given to the player by default?

[hr]LevelLord 5.) Items cannot decorate the level. They are an added extra to by laid over the level after its done. Don't fill blank space with points as it looks repetitive and when the points are got, the space will still be there.
[hr]Background tiles have long been part of my primary focus, but putting the items in only after the level is finished is something I'd never thought of before... must try that strategy.

[hr]
My main issue with points is the general meaninglessness of the high scores table... it's not particularly indicative of a player's skill level. This thread '[url=http://andy.durdin.net/keen/modding/viewtopic.php?t=334]On the topic of points...[/url]' over at K:M has a more thorough explanation of this issue.

I'll be alot more comfortable when the Infinite Lives patch is completed. The only thing that remains is to keep a secondary counter of how many points are collected in a given level (using the unused Next Keen At counter) and only add that value when the level is actually completed. Then there'll be a finite maximum high score so the rankings will more accurately represent skill level.
